stem: A 26-year-old client at 28 weeks gestation is evaluated for elevated blood pressure. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Screening for hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. Client is a 26-year-old female at 28 weeks gestation.
Background: The client is G2P1. This is her second trimester. She has no history of high blood pressure before this pregnancy. Initial vital signs were concerning for hypertension.
Assessment: At 10:00, the client's blood pressure was 148/94 mmHg, and repeated at 10:15 it was 150/92 mmHg. She has gained 5 lbs in the last week and reports that her rings are fitting tightly. Urine dipstick showed +1 protein.
Recommendation: Obtain a urine protein quantification and complete lab screen to evaluate for preeclampsia.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Blood Pressure148/94 (repeat 150/92)Hypertensive (>140/90)
Urine Protein+1 (Dipstick)Proteinuria present
Protein/Creatinine Ratio0.35 mg/mgAbnormal (>0.3)
Serum Creatinine0.9 mg/dLNormal
Platelets180,000 /mm³Normal

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 148/94, HR 82, RR 18, T 98.4°F. Client denies headache or vision changes.

actionOptions.text: Initiate a 24-hour urine collection for total protein.
Instruct the client to record daily weights and report > 2lb gain.
Administer STAT Magnesium Sulfate loading dose.
Recommend a strictly salt-free diet for the remainder of pregnancy.

parameterOptions.text: Blood pressure monitoring twice weekly at minimum.
Maternal report of visual disturbances or epigastric pain.
Deep tendon reflexes and respiratory rate.
Daily measurement of fasting blood glucose.

rationale.correct: This client has Preeclampsia (c2). The diagnosis requires BP > 140/90 after 20 weeks gestation PLUS Proteinuria (dipstick +1 or Ratio > 0.3). If she had high BP WITHOUT proteinuria, it would be Gestational HTN. Priority actions involve confirming the protein total with a 24-hour collection (a1) and tracking rapid fluid retention via weight (a2). Parameter monitoring focuses on the worsening of symptoms like BP (p1) and neurological/liver involvement (p2).
clinicalPearls: Prot/Creat ratio > 0.3 is the modern standard for diagnosing preeclampsia instead of waiting for a 24-hour urine.
Gestational HTN is 'just the BP' after 20 weeks. Preeclampsia is the BP 'plus the protein' (or other organ damage).
Magnesium is NOT indicated yet as the BP is below 160/110 and there are no severe features.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Sodium restriction is NOT recommended for preeclampsia because it doesn't solve the underlying placental issue and can actually reduce uterine blood flow.

mnemonic.title: Pre-E Triad (Old but bold)
mnemonic.expansion: 1. Hypertension. 2. Proteinuria. 3. Edema (Now secondary but common).
